texts.ru: Курбонова Дилбар жительница  района Вахдат.Возраст  38 лет, замужем,имеет 2 детей.Образование среднее.Дилбар занимается сельским хозяйством,она имееет небольшой земельный участок на котором сеет овощи.Имеет опыт в сельском хозяйстве более 10 лет.Собрав урожай клиентка делает запасы  для своей семьи,а лишнее реализует на рынке.В данный момент Дильбар хочет купить минеральные удобрения,что бы получить качественный урожай.Планирует погасить кредит в течении 6 месяцев.
texts.en:
Dilbar K. is 38 and lives in Vahdat district. She is married with two children and has a high school education. Dilbar has a small plot of land where she grows vegetables for a living. She has been in the agricultural business for over 10 years. Dilbar keeps some of her harvest for her own family and sells the rest at the market. Dilbar is applying for a loan to buy mineral fertilizer, which will increase the quality of her harvest. She plans to repay the loan within 6 months.

Translated from Russian by Susie Armitage, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Lucila

texts.es:
Lucila tiene 40 años, es madre soltera de dos hijos de 8 y 18 años de edad, vive en la casa de su madre situada al costado del mercado municipal.

Proviene de una familia muy humilde, por tal motivo solo pudo terminar la primaria.

Lucila posee un comedor dentro del mercado municipal en donde tiene venta de comidas típicas como ser: empanadas de mandioca y de harina, butifarra (comida típica paraguaya), asadito carne y chanco, etc. El negocio ya cuenta con 15 años de antigüedad y le da la posibilidad de costear los estudios primarios y universitarios de sus dos hijos.

Recuerda que sus inicios como comerciante fueron muy duros y que con mucho esfuerzo pudo hacerse de capital para montar su propio negocio.

Hoy día cuenta con una clientela muy bien formada a pesar de la competencia que existe en dicho lugar. Mucha gente asiste a su local para disfrutar de las delicias que ella cocina y el mismo se llena generalmente los fines de semanas.

Desea adquirir una computadora para sus hijos, y es por ese motivo que recurre a la Fundación Paraguaya, a fin de hacerse acreedora de un préstamo que le dará la posibilidad de adquirir dicha máquina para ayudar a sus hijos con el estudio y también llevar un mejor control de su stock de mercaderías y ventas.
texts.en:
Lucila, 40, is the single mother of two children ages 8 and 18. She lives in her mother's house located next to the municipal market. She comes from a very humble family, and was only able to complete her primary education. Lucila has a lunch counter inside the municipal market, where she sells typical meals such as tapioca and flour pies, butifarra (a typical Paraguayan food), grilled meats, etc. The business, already 15 years old, gives her the opportunity to pay for the primary and university education of her two children. She recalls that initially business was very hard, and that it took great effort to raise the capital to start her own business. Now she has a loyal clientele in spite of the competition in her location. Many people come to her shop to enjoy the delights that she creates, and it usually fills up on the weekends also. She wants to buy a computer for her children, which is why she has come to Foundation Paraguay. She desires a loan that will allow her to acquire the computer to help her children with their studies, and also to keep better control of her inventory and sales.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a computer

loans.name: Shavkat

texts.ru: Собирджонов Шавкат житель Гиссарского района.Возраст 28 лет .Женат и имеет троих детей.Работает водителем пассажирской маршрутки. Маршрутка марки"Газель" его собственная.Это дело является единственным источником дохода его семьи. Неделю , как произошла поломка автомашины . Кредит решил получить сразу как узнал о возможности получить кредит. Закпив необходимые запчасти он сможет сделать капитальный ремонт автомобиля. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Shavkat S. lives in the Gissar district. He is 28 years old, married, and has three children. He drives a minibus taxi for a living. He has his own Gazelle brand minibus. This work is the only source of income for his family. A week ago the minibus broke down. The minute Shavkat learned of the availability of loans he decided to take one out. Once he buys the needed parts he can make major repairs on the vehicle. The loan will be repaid over 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of car parts

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en: Benjamin B. is fifty years old. Benjamin is a father of four children who are currently in the basic school. He lives in a rented apartment with his family in a town in the Ashanti region of Ghana called Obuasi. Benjamin loves trading a lot, the business through which he supports his family with income. He sells food items such as maize, rice, yam, etc in the market square in his community. He says that he also distributes to some food vendors and restaurant operators. He has been in business for six years. Benjamin says he buys his stocks from the farmers in his community and those in nearby towns. He wants a loan to buy the stocks in bulk so that he can distribute to more customers. Benjamin is a member of a group called Philippians in his community. The group members guarantee for one another as collateral to be able to access the loan and support one another in handling repayment.

loans.use: To purchase larger quantities of maize, yam and rice.

loans.name: Ieng

texts.en:
K., 38 years old, is a vegetable seller from Siem Reap Province. She runs her business in the area of the Psatom Tmey Market and sells different kinds of vegetables like cabbages, potatoes, and morning glories. She currently earns an average of $5 a day and has been running the business for more than one year.

K. is married to Mr. Khout Sarthoun who is a motorcycle taxi driver and also works with her in selling vegetables. She now cares for three children, all of whom are single and attend school. K. hopes to enlarge her business; thus she is applying for this loan ($1,000) to purchase more vegetables for sell and to build a bathroom for family hygiene.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables for sell and build a bathroom

loans.name: Hidoyat

texts.en:
Hidoyat devotes herself to the production of vegetables. For this reason she remains as long as possible on her lands, dedicating herself to the care and fertilizations of her fields: with all this effort it is possible to obtain a good harvest and sell the products, with the aim of offering her two children an education and personal development appropriate to their age. 

Hidoyat is thinking of opening a grocery store in her house to increase her family's income. This requires investment, so Hidoyat is asking for your help to purchase a larger quantity of manure and fertilizer. We hope to count on you, and appeal to your collaborative spirit.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia is 46 years old, and she is married with 4 children. She sells provisions and drinks. She has been in this business for a long time. She needs the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more provisions and drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions and drinks to sell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes A. is currently in the business of selling at her shop and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Agnes is 47 years old and is married. Her husband is a soldier. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Hou

texts.en:
Mrs. Hou C., 38, lives in a medium-sized wooden house in Banteay Meanchey Province with her other three family members and earns a living by selling Khmer noodles to nearby neighborhoods. Her husband, Rong, 39, drives a motor taxi and also has a job as a requirement worker. The couple can make a daily income of $6 and are very responsible to their two single children, providing food, clothing, and medical care. 

Rong’s motor taxi income is currently inconsistent due to frequent mechanical problems, so Hou is requesting a loan to buy a new motorcycle to replace it.

loans.use: To buy a new motorcycle to replace an old one broken.

loans.name: Nohemi

texts.es:
Es casada y tiene 3 hijos.

Queriendo apoyar a su esposo, en los gastos de hogar, elige la venta de productos por catalogo, ya que no tiene un horario fijo y asi puede atender a su familia, le ha hido muy bien en las ventas, pero ahora necesita invertir en mas productos, de mayor novedad para atraer mas clientes, y ofrecer lo mejor a los clientes que ya tiene.

este ingreso que le generan estas ventas es parte fundamental en su hogar ya que con el sustenta los estudios de sus hijos, que ya cursan carreras profesionales.

Apoyemosla.
texts.en:
She is married and has 3 children. Wanting to help her husband with the household expenses, she joined the catalogue sales business, since it doesn’t require a set schedule and she can tend to her family. She’s done very well in sales, but now she needs to invest in more, newer products so she can attract more customers, and so she can provide the best to the customers she already has. The income that these sales generate is crucial to her home, as it is used to pay for her children’s studies, who are both studying professional careers. Let’s support her.

Translated from Spanish by Maya Wisnievitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY GOODS

loans.name: Vida

texts.en:
Vida B. is 31 years old. She is married and has given birth to four children: two sons and two daughters. She says all her children are currently in primary school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Kofiase. It is a farming/trading community near Dormaa, the district capital, in the Brong Ahafo region. Her husband is a mason by profession.

Vida is a food vendor. She prepares and sells rice and stew. She prepares the food in her place of residence and sells on the street from morning to evenings. She procures bags of maize and other ingredients from nearby towns. Vida has been in business for two years and wants a loan to procure bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk. She is hopeful to expand her business and give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To procure bags of rice

loans.name: Luz

texts.es: Luz tiene 37 años, vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos. Se dedica a la venta de artesanías y frazadas (cobertores de cama) que lleva hasta otra ciudad para su comercialización, su esposo la ayuda a realizar estos largos viajes, ya que no puede cargar sola la mercadería que compra. Este trabajo es una gran ayuda para la economía de su casa, a pesar de que es arriesgado por los largos viajes, debido a los accidentes en carretera, pero las ganancias la animan a continuar con esta actividad, ya que su meta es ahorrar lo suficiente para emprender otro negocio que le permita estar en su misma ciudad. Es la segunda vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP, está muy satisfecha por la labor que viene realizando y se compromete, una vez más, a seguir siendo responsable y solidaria con su grupo. El dinero que está solicitando será invertido en la compra de más frazadas y artesanías.
texts.en:
Luz is 37 years old and she lives with her husband and 3 children. She sells crafts and bed covers, which she takes to another city to sell. Her husband helps her with these long trips since she can’t carry all of the merchandise by herself. This job is a big help to her household economy, even though it’s dangerous because of the long trips and traffic accidents on the road. However, the earnings motivate her to continue with this line of work, since her goal is to save enough to start another business that would allow her to work in her own town. This is the second loan she has had with MFP. She is happy with the work she is doing and promises, again, to continue being responsible and in solidarity with her group. The loan she is requesting will be invested in the purchase of more bed covers and crafts.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more merchandise

loans.name: Nkechi

texts.en: Nkechi sells Kunu (A locally made drink from guinea corn). Kunu is a popular drink in Nigeria. She hopes for a loan in the amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more ingredients to make more kunu to sell. She is 31 years old and married, with a child. She is very grateful to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients like millet, joro and guinea corn to make more kunu to sell.

loans.name: Ni Putu Supadmi

texts.en: Ni Putu Supadmi (DNR.M-0577) is a 31-year-old female living in the town of Melaya. She is married and has two school-aged children. Ni Putu Supadmi owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over ten years and earns approximately 200,000 IDR a month. In 2007, Ni Putu Supadmi joined DINARI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is now requesting a new loan of 4,500,000 IDR which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. The loan will be her 4th from DINARI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. About DINARI: The mission of DINARI is to strive for the preservation of the environment, to empower the poor, and to provide socio-economic development opportunities to small business owners. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Bahasa while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. ***************************************************** Ni Putu Supadmi - (DNR.M-0577) merupakan 31 tahun wanita. Dia (perempuan) tinggal di kota Melaya. Dia (perempuan) menikah dan memiliki 2 anak usia sekolah. Untuk membiayai hidup, Ni Putu Supadmi memiliki & menjalankan usaha. Bisnis beroperasi di sektor pertanian. Tujuan utama bisnis tersebut adalah memelihara ternak. Meskipun bukan satu-satunya sarana untuk menghasilkan pendapatan, sumber utama penghasilan bisnis tersebut terutama berasal dari beternak babi untuk dijual. Ni Putu Supadmi sudah menjalankan bisnis ini selama lebih dari 10 tahun. Dari kegiatan-kegiatan ini, Ni Putu Supadmi menghasilkan sekitar 200,000 IDR sebulan. Dalam 2007, Ni Putu Supadmi bergabung DINARI untuk mendapatkan akses ke layanan keuangan untuk membantu meningkatkan -nya kondisi kehidupan dan kemampuan untuk menjalankan kegiatan bisnis. Ni Putu Supadmi telah berhasil melunasi pinjaman sebelumnya dari DINARI. Dia (perempuan) sekarang meminta pinjaman baru sebesar 4,500,000 IDR. Pinjaman saat ini akan digunakan untuk untuk membeli pakan ternak & pasokan lain. Pinjaman ini akan menjadi 4th pinjaman yang diambil oleh peminjam dari DINARI. Ni Putu Supadmi berencana untuk menggunakan pendapatan tambahan yang dihasilkan dari bisnis untuk membayar biaya sekolah anak-anak peminjam. Tentang DINARI: Misi DINARI adalah memperjuangkan kelestarian lingkungan, memberdayakan kaum miskin, dan menyediakan kesempatan pembangunan sosial ekonomi bagi pemilik usaha kecil. *Catatan: Untuk memaksimalkan efisiensi & menurunkan biaya, pinjaman ini ditempelkan menggunakan templat sehingga dapat diterjemahkan otomatis oleh Kiva. Mengingat bahwa terjemahan manual atas profil memakan biaya besar, Kiva menciptakan templat ini untuk Mitra Lapangan untuk memungkinkan mereka terus menempelkan pinjaman dalam Bahasa sambil memberikan informasi yang bermutu & akurat kepada para pemberi pinjaman Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Trong

texts.en: Trong L. is 25, married and has one child who attends school. His wife stays at home; she is responsible for daily housework, cooking, and caring for their child. She also grows different kinds of vegetable for sale. Trong L. works driving a truck for a small firm, but for a long time he has had difficulty with transportation in getting to work, because his workplace is far from his house. He therefore requests a loan in order to buy a motorcycle, to make it easier to get to work, and also to help his family’s traveling needs.

loans.use: To buy a vehicle to make it easier to ride to work

loans.name: Vinancia

texts.en:
Vinancia P., age 60, is from the village of Tuburan. Vinancia is married and has three grown children. To make a living, Vinancia owns and operates a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Vinancia has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Vinancia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services. She hoped to help improve her living situation and to increase her ability to engage in business activities. Vinancia has successfully repaid three previous loans from PMPC. Vinancia is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Assétou

texts.fr:
Assétou Koné a 46 ans, mariée et mère de trois enfants. Elle vit avec son époux et leurs enfants à Sanoubougou II, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Assétou Koné  après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est initiée à cette activité de stockage et  de commercialisation des  céréales (maïs, mil, sorgho) depuis maintenant plus de trois ans. Elle dispose d’un magasin au grand marché de la ville de Sikasso. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a plus de quatre année. Après 6 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association Benkadi de Sanoubougou II), elle est actuellement à son deuxième prêt individuel. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce nouveau prêt, 6 sacs de riz, 8 sacs de maïs, 5 sacs de sorgho, 2 sacs d’arachide  et 4 sacs de mil. Elle achète le riz à Niono (région de Ségou) et les autres céréales dans les localités environnantes de la ville de Sikasso avant de les revendre au comptant et en détail à une clientèle composée généralement de chefs de famille.
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt, un bénéfice mensuel de 250 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour  contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Assétou Koné, age 46, is married and a mother of three. She lives with her husband and their children in Sanoubougou II, a working-class neighborhood in the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republique of Mali.) Three years ago, after having tried a number of activities without success, Assétou Koné began to stock and sell grains (such as corn, millet and sorghum.) She has a store in Sikasso's grand market. In order to satisfy the demands of her growing clientele, she joined the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso four years ago. After 6 group loans with a women's association from her neighborhood (Association Benkadi de Sanoubougou II,) she is now on her second individual loan. Her previous loans were all repaid according to the terms. With this new loan, she plans to purchase 6 bags of rice, 8 bags of corn, 5 bags of sorghum, 2 bags of peanuts and 4 sacks of millet. She buys the rice in Niono (in the Ségou region) and the other grains from the area surrounding Sikasso. She retails the grain for cash. Her clients are mostly heads of households. She expects to realize a monthly benefit of 250 000 FCFA from this loan, which she will use to support the family's expenses, make loan payments, and invest in her business.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bulk grains.

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily is happily married to Ruben. The couple helps each other so that they could sustain the needs of their family. Emily is selling native cakes.  Aside from this, she also buy and sell salted eggs in wholesale price and sell in retail price.  Her income in the business is very helpful in sending their children to school and to their daily needs at home. Her desire of improving the business gives her the idea of requesting for additional business capital from KIVA lenders. She hopes to avail the amount of PHP5, 000. 

Emily knows how to make salted eggs because sometimes, she is just purchasing ducks eggs in the market and will be the one doing the process of making salted eggs. The process is very easy said Emily. Having the knowledge of making salted eggs motivated her to work harder aiming to have bigger capital in order to buy ducks that produces eggs for her salted making. But for now, since she doesn’t have the needed capital, Emily will patiently improve her vending till she could reach out for her dreams.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Rubeje

texts.en: Rubeje T. is currently in the business of selling beans, sugar etc and is requesting a loan to stock charcoal to sell.  Rubeje is 35 years old and is Married with a husband that is a driver. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock charcoal to sell

loans.name: Bolanle

texts.en: Bolanle is 28 years old and married with two children. She sells provisions and has been in the business for the past six years. She hopes for the loan amount of N50,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Sabougnouma  sont des femmes mariées vivant dans des foyers polygames à Dangassa, un village située entre le Mali et la république de Guinée Conakry. Dangassa est à 70  kilomètres de Bamako (la capitale du Mali). Les femmes du groupe Sabougnouma ont en moyenne  trente ans,  trois enfants et se sont connues par des liens de famille, de voisinage et d’activités. 
Ce groupe de femmes est spécialisé dans la fabrication et la vente des articles de poteries (canaris, jarre etc.)
Par souci de mieux produire et découler facilement les poteries qu’elles fabriquent, elles ont fait recours au  programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur premier prêt solidaire.
Elles envisagent produire en moyenne 50 canaris de volumes différentes par mois. Elles possèdent la matière première principale qui est de l’argile : sélectionnée, mouillée et pétrie avec la latérite pour donner la forme désirée. Une fois les canaris fabriquées, elles sont  disposées au soleil pour être  séchées puis brûlées par un grand feu, décorées et  rendre lisse les articles.
Une partie de la production est vendue  dans le  marché de Dangassa et la majeure partie est acheminée par pirogue à Bamako pour être vendue.
Elles espèrent  réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  18. 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour payer l’échéance du prêt et contribuer aux dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
The women in the Sabougnouma group are married and live in polygamous households in Dangassa, a village located between Mali and the republic of Guniea-Conakry. Dangassa is 70 kilometres from Bamako (the capital of Mali). The women of the Sabougnouma group have an average age of 30, three children and know each other through family, neighbourly and business connections.

This group of women specialises in making and selling pottery (jugs, jars etc.).

In order to improve production and sales of the pottery they make, they went to Soro Yiriwaso’s loan programme and are on their first group loan.

They envisage producing an average of 50 jugs of different volumes each month. They have the main raw material, which is clay: selected, moistened and kneaded with laterite to give it the desired shape. Once made, the jugs are left to dry in the sun, then baked in a large fire, decorated and glazed.

A portion of the produce is sold at Dangassa market and the majority is transported by canoe to be sold in Bamako.

They hope to make an average monthly profit of 18,000 FCFA which will be used to pay off the loan and contribute to household expenses.

Translated from French by Lara Francis, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To cover labour costs and transport of pottery

loans.name: Mary Grace

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal María Inmaculada se formó en la ciudad de Manta en la provincia de Manabí, este es un puerto marítimo muy visitado por los turistas nacionales y extranjeros, la mayoría de  sus habitantes  viven de la pesca artesanal.

Mary Grace es oriunda de Guayaquil se radicó en  Manta hace 18 años, vive en el barrio San Pedro en el cantón Manta con su hija de quince años, es enfermera de profesión trabaja en el centro de salud hace un año, también tiene un  negocio de víveres en él ofrece todos los productos de primera necesidad, además vende otros artículos de acuerdo a la época así: en inicio  de  clases vende utilices escolares, en la época de navideña arboles y adornos  y en carnaval vende bebidas refrescantes, lleva cinco años con su tienda; cada tres días tiene el turno de 24 horas en el centro de salud por lo que su hija es la encargada de atender la tienda.

Con el préstamo solicitado a la Fundación ESPOIR va a comprar un congelador y vitrinas para exhibir sus productos, ampliar y renovar su negocio. 

Nuestra socia tiene muchos sueños entre ellos montar en casa una distribuidora de helados, y en el futuro tener una Fundación para ayudar a las personas de escasos recursos   y no descarta la posibilidad de hacerlos realidad  ya que es  una persona muy emprendedora.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank "María Inmaculada" was formed in the city of Manta, in the province of Manabí. Manta is a tourist coastal town that is visited by many from all over the country and abroad. The majority of the residents lives off traditional subsistence fishing. Mary Grace is from Guayaquil and moved to Manta 18 years ago. She lives in the San Pedro neighborhood, in the Manta canton with her 15-year-old daughter. She is a nurse and she has worked in a health center for a year. She also has a business selling all manner of basic supplies for the home and other seasonal products. When school starts, she sells school supplies; during the holiday season, she sells ornaments and trees; and during carnival, she sells soft drinks. She has had her store for five years. Every three days, when she has a 24-hour shift at the health center, her daughter works at the store. With the loan she has requested from Kiva partner Fundación ESPOIR, Mary Grace will buy a freezer and display cases to show off her products. She will also expand and renovate the store. Mary Grace has many dreams -- among them, to start her own home business selling ice cream, and in the future, to start a foundation to help low-income people. Mary Grace doesn't discount the possibility of making her dreams into reality, as she is a very entrepreneurial person.

Translated from Spanish by Violeta Rubiani, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying a freezer and display cases

loans.name: Ijoma

texts.en:
Ijoma sells bags of rice and beans at wholesale prices. She loves this business because her customers pay cash when they purchase her goods. She hopes to expand her business in future.

Ijoma is 48 years old and is married with four children who are all excelling in their school and trade.

Ijoma hopes for a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more bags of beans and rice to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of beans and rice to sell

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a twenty-seven-year-old married man living in Bint Jbeil, Southern Lebanon with his wife and their two children. Ali has been selling plowing machines since 1996; he requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy merchandise for his work. This is the first time that Ali has requested a loan. His friends, neighbors and relatives are his clients. Ali hopes to expand his work.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for his work.

loans.name: Wilmer Alberto

texts.es:
El señor Wilmer se dedica a laborar arduamente en una empresa en el departamento de bodega y almacenamiento.El crédito que solicita es para el mejoramiento de su vivienda por lo que va a usar el crédito para comprar zinc y clavos para el techo de su casa por lo que antes se encontraba en mal estado y el agua se pasaba en invierno.
 
Ha trabajado con Ceprodel 2 años y afirma que sus créditos con Ceprodel le han ayudado mucho por lo que ha venido mejorando su casa de habitación.
texts.en:
Wilmer works hard in a company in their grocery and storage department. He will use his funding to buy zinc metal sheeting and nails to repair his house's roof, which is in very poor condition and let in a lot of rain water during winter. This is his second loan with CEPRODEL; he has collaborated with CEPRODEL for two years. Wilmer states that the funding from CEPRODEL has been of great help to him with his home repairs.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy zinc metal sheeting and nails.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase food products and household goods for resale

loans.name: Van

texts.en:
Mrs. Van R. is 64 years old and she lives in Dei Edth Kaoh Phos village in Kandal province. She is a vegetable seller who is able to earn money to support her family living.

However hard this family tries to work with their business, they are not able to earn enough income. In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Van R. decided to ask for a loan to buy more vegetables to sell in order to expand her business.

Mrs. Van R. is a widow with two children, one of whom is a worker in a cake shop, while the other helps her mother.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Dolores Del Carmen

texts.es: Dolores del Carmen P. D. F. D. 47 años D. edad, resiD. en Ilopango, ubicado en el departamento D. San Salvador, lugar en el cual vive junto a su esposo el cual trabaja como carpintero y su hija D. 17 años D. edad, la cual se dedica a estudiar. Dolores D. dedica a la venta D. cosméticos, los cuales comercializa en su hogar y así mismo D. forma ambulante con sus vecinas y amigas D. la colonia. También hace almuerzos en su casa, los cuales ya tiene cinco años D. comercializar, lo que le ha permitido contar con varios clientes fijos. Dolores solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad D. materia prima para la elaboración D. la comida, y D. esta forma poder atender  a más clientes, los que muchas veces no pueden adquirir sus alimentos ya que se terminan con rapidez, así también ella espera comprar más cosméticos en diferentes precios, lo cual le permita abarcar mayor cantidad D. clientes. Esto la llena D. mucho ilusión puesto que le permitirá aumentar sus ventas y D. esta forma ayudarle a su esposo con todos los gastos del hogar.
texts.en:
. Dolores del Carmen P. D. F., 47, lives in Ilopango, San Salvador department, with her husband, who is a carpenter, and their 17-year-old daughter, who is a student. Dolores sells cosmetics from home and door-to-door among her friends and neighbors. She also prepares lunches at home which she has been selling for five years now; this has created a regular customer base. Dolores is asking for funding to buy a larger quantity of ingredients for her lunches so that she can increase the number of customers served; often, some are unable to buy her lunches because she runs out of them too soon. She also hopes to buy more cosmetics at a variety of prices so that she can attract a wider variety of customers. This fills her with hope that her sales will increase and she will be able to help her husband meet household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cosmetics and ingredients for meals preparation.

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
Salvacion A. is a 49-year-old married woman who supports her family with peanut processing (salted, coated, boiled peanuts) and a vegetable garden. She lives in Brgy Asia Hinoba-an, Negros Occidental with her husband, Artemio, and their three children who are between 24 and 29 years old.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her peanut processing (salted, coated, boiled peanuts) and vegetable garden businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,000.

Salvacion is now borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she can expand her peanut processing (salted, coated, boiled peanuts) and vegetable garden. This will be her eighth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000, which she paid off within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Salvacion aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Ileana Guadalupe

texts.es:
La Sra. G. B. es una profesora que trabaja en la Esc. Santa María de la Merced que esta ubicada en el municipio del Viejo, departamento de Chinandega.

Ella va a utilizar el crédito para pagar los gastos universitarios de su hija ya que esta en el último año de la Universidad y necesita para los gastos de la monografía.

Este es primer crédito que tiene con la Institución pero ella dice estar muy agradecida por la comprensión que le ha otorgado Ceprodel y espera seguir trabajando con nosotros.
texts.en:
Ms. G. is a profesional woman who works in the “Santa María de la Merced” school, in the city of Viejo, in the Chinandega department. She will use the money from this loan to pay university expenses for her daughter, now that she is in her final year. This will be her first loan through the institution, but she says that she is very grateful for CEPRODEL’s understanding and she hopes to be able to continue to work with us.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Tuition

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase tailoring materials in bulk

loans.name: Lucy Aurora

texts.es:
Lucy es socia del Banco Comunal Triunfo.
Lucy es casada, tiene 40 años y 5 hijos, Lucy tiene un taller de confecciones en un local alquilado ubicado en el centro de la ciudad, actividad que realiza todos los días. Además Lucy esta implementando un recreo en su casa que se ubica cerca al terminal de la ciudad.
Lucy necesita un préstamo de 1500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de cerveza y gaseosa.
Los sueños de Lucy son ampliar sus negocios y poner en funcionamiento su negocio.
texts.en:
Lucy is a member of the Triunfo Communal Bank.

Lucy is married, 40 years old, and has 5 children. Lucy has an alterations/seamstress shop rented and located in the center of the city, in where she works everyday. Further, Lucy has a recreation place in her home that is located near the terminal of the city.

Lucy needs a loan of 1500 soles, money that will be used to buy beer and refreshments.

Lucy’s dreams are to expand and run her businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beer and refreshments.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a 32-year-old single lady. She has been selling clothes for the past three years. She was formerly selling jewelry to earn a living. Blessed is the name of a group in Faulu Kenya (a Kiva partner) where Sarah saves her money. Being in this group has enabled her to service two loans from Faulu Kenya; this is because she is guaranteed by the group members.  

She has currently requested a loan of 44,000 Kenyan shillings from Faulu Kenya. With this loan, she wants to add more stock of clothes. She hopes to employ more people in the future.

loans.use: To add stock of clothes

loans.name: Lakham

texts.en:
Lakham is a 35 year-old clothes seller. He sells second-hand clothes to people in a local marketplace. He has been in this business for 2 years. Lakham is married and has a 3 year-old son. The primary challenges that he faces are getting capital and building a stall for sales. In addition to selling clothes, Lakham also sells tea leaves and bananas. 

Lakham plans to use the 40,000 KES loan to purchase more clothing inventory to sell. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 KES. In the future, Lakham hopes to get a permanent selling location and to buy a wider variety of goods. In 5 years, he dreams of developing his business and getting his own shop on land that he owns.

Lakham describes himself as hardworking, optimistic, and business-minded.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing stock to sell.
